image.altText: Sgt Richard Monei sits at table with police hat next to him

items.synopsis: Richard Monaei joined the Queensland Police Service when he was 18. He's now an advocate so other First Nations people don't suffer as he did.

title.children: Racism forced Richard out of Queensland Police. He says a newly announced review is 'long overdue'

image.altText: Empty streets in a rural town

title.children: CheckMate: What's the evidence for 60,000 years of Indigenous history?

image.altText: A selfie of a serious man with shaved hair next to his large brown dog.

image.altText: An aerial view of a flock of pelicans on a landscape.

title.children: As new Murray Darling Basin rules get debated, scientists say there's a clear path to improving the rivers' health

image.altText: Close up of Catherine King

items.synopsis: Transport Minister Catherine King has pledged airfares will soon come down, saying Qatar Airways is "not the only airline that adds to competition".

title.children: Catherine King says airfares 'will come down' as other airlines increase capacity

image.altText: Naomi Bowden

items.synopsis: Through tears NaomiÂ Bowden tells a NSW inquiry into birth trauma how distressing it was to have police take her stillborn daughter and put her in an ice box in front of her.

title.children: Naomi speaks up about the 'disrespectful' treatment she received after her baby was stillborn

image.altText: A composite image of Anthony Albanese and Scott Morrison

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Scott Morrison has warned that his successor should not be "too keen" to accept an invitation to China, as Anthony Albanese prepares to visit Beijing within months.

title.children: Scott Morrison says Anthony Albanese shouldn't rush to visit Bejiing this year

image.altText: A satellite image showing Australia, New Zealand and an enormous mushroom cloud from a volcanic eruption in the Pacific ocean

items.synopsis: In January 2022, a mega explosion from the Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha'apai volcano generated a coast-battering tsunami and vivid sunsets.Â Now we know the extent of the eruption's devastation below the waves.

image.altText: Danny Masterson wears a face mask looking straight ahead in front of an orange background.

title.children: That '70s Show actor Danny Masterson jailed for 30 years to life for raping two women

image.altText: A Warriors NRL player prepares to catch the ball during a match.

items.synopsis: As they make their first finals appearances in five years, the Warriors are not prepared to take a risk on playing injured Dally M Medal favourite Shaun Johnson against the Panthers.

image.altText: An Australian male batter prepares to hit the ball in an ODI against South Africa.

items.synopsis: Marnus Labuschagne comes to Australia's rescue in the role of concussion substitute, lifting his sideÂ to a three-wicket win over South Africa in the first ODI at Bloemfontein.

title.children: Concussion sub Labuschagne guides Australia to ODI win over South Africa

image.altText: China 6G

items.synopsis: Chinese state media has pointed to Huawei's new smartphone as evidence the United States'Â attempts to curtail China's microchip development are failing.Â So how significant is the tech in the new phone and what does it mean for the "chip wars"?Â

title.children: Huawei launched a new phone without fanfare last week. But the technology it uses has sparked intense debate

image.altText: A group of people sit on the water's edge on the sand and put snorkel gear on.

items.synopsis: An island home to an environmental education centre used for student campsÂ is now powered by the largest renewable energy system built on a state school site.

title.children: Tropical island paradise school becomes completely powered by renewables

image.altText: Plastic two litres of Coles milk in the dairy cabinet.

items.synopsis: Supermarket giant Coles is pushing to buy two milk factories, but Australian dairy farmers say it will give the retailer too much control over farm gate milk prices.

title.children: Farmers call on ACCC to block Coles milk factory deal amid 'bargaining power' fears

image.altText: A comparison of teeth from three koalas species.

items.synopsis: Scientists sayÂ teeth from the speciesÂ have been found at a 25-million-year-old fossil bedÂ south of Alice Springs. It is the first-ever record ofÂ koalasÂ living in the Northern Territory.

title.children: New prehistoric koala species 'about the size of a cat' discovered in Central Australian fossil bed

image.altText: Catherine King standing speaking wearing a bright red blazer.

image.altText: A huge plume of smoke billows above a bushfire burning in grassland near a country road.

items.synopsis: The fire near Cecil Plains has burnt through aboutÂ 1,000 hectares since it was sparked by lightning on Tuesday.

title.children: Bushfire raging in Queensland state forest jumps containment lines

image.altText: People wearing face masks try out the latest iPhone handsets at an Apple Store in Beijing.

items.synopsis: Wall Street finished lower overnight as China's ban on iPhones saw investors nervous about what it could mean for other tech stocks, while ASIC is suing AustralianSuper for allegedly failing to address multiple superannuation accounts. Follow live.

title.children: China's iPhone ban sends Apple and Wall Street lower, ASIC sues AustralianSuper, ASX set for modest gain

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you didn't see it yesterday, Philip Lowe has gone out fighting in his final speech as Reserve Bank governor, warning that Australia's living standards are at risk without productivity reform. And on the way out, he's taken a swipe at the media over the reporting of his now infamous signal that interest rates would stay near zero until 2024. Meanwhile, corporate regulator ASIC is suing AustralianSuper alleging it failed to merge multiple member and continued to charge multiple fees and insurance premiums. You can listen to senior business correspondent Peter Ryan's take on the last 24 hours in the business world here, or below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ðŸŽ§ RBA governor Philip Lowe takes aim at productivity and the media in final speech

children.content: If you didn't see it yesterday,
Philip Lowe
has gone out fighting in his final speech as Reserve Bank governor, warning that
Australia's living standards are at risk without productivity reform
And on the way out, he's taken a
swipe at the media
over the reporting of his now
infamous signal that interest rates would stay near zero until 2024
Meanwhile, corporate regulator ASIC is suing
AustralianSuper
alleging it failed to merge multiple member and
continued to charge multiple fees
and insurance premiums.
You can listen to
senior business correspondent Peter Ryan's
take on the
last 24 hours in the business world here
, or below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: AustralianSuper has responded to the news this morning that ASIC has launched legal action against the superannuation fund, alleging it had failed to identify and combine multiple accounts. Here's the full statement from a spokesperson: "AustralianSuper regrets that its processes to identify and combine multiple accounts did not cover all  instances of multiple member accounts. "This should not have happened, and we apologise unreservedly to members. " AustralianSuper self-reported this issue and has fully cooperated with ASIC and APRA on this matter  and, separately, with ASIC for its 2022 industry review of the management of multiple member accounts. "AustralianSuper implemented a member remediation program for this matter earlier this year, which is  now substantially complete. "Having identified this issue, we have strengthened our processes to identify and combine multiple  accounts and remain committed to minimising these for members. "AustralianSuper will continue to work with ASIC to bring these proceedings to a resolution."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AustralianSuper responds to ASIC's legal action, says it self-reported the issue

children.content: AustralianSuper
has responded to the news this morning that ASIC has launched legal action against the superannuation fund, alleging it had failed to identify and combine multiple accounts.
Here's the full statement from a spokesperson:
"AustralianSuper regrets that its processes to identify and combine multiple accounts did not cover all  instances of multiple member accounts.
"This
should not have happened
, and we
apologise unreservedly
to members.
AustralianSuper self-reported this issue
and has fully cooperated with ASIC and APRA on this matter  and, separately, with ASIC for its 2022 industry review of the management of multiple member accounts.
"AustralianSuper implemented a member remediation program for this matter earlier this year, which is  now substantially complete.
"Having identified this issue,
we have strengthened our processes to identify and combine multiple  accounts
and remain committed to minimising these for members.
"AustralianSuper will continue to work with ASIC to bring these proceedings to a resolution."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As I mentioned earlier, US jobless claims have fallen to their lowest level since February â€” dipping by 13,000 to 216,000 claims made in the week ending September 2. Economists had predicted a relatively small lift to occur in the numbers. So what was behind the change? Markets economist at NAB, Taylor Nugent, notes that the surprise fall could be for a couple of reasons. "The figures could have been distorted by holiday factors, coming a week before Labour Day, and Hurricane Idalia â€“ where the usual reaction after a natural disaster is lower claims initially, followed by a jump," he said in a morning note. This most recent fall marks the fourth straight weekly decline in US jobless claims, and comes after the US Labor Department last week said jobs growth had picked up in August. All in all, the data suggests the US job market remains relatively tight, despite other figures indicating it has started to soften.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's behind the fall in the US jobless claims?

children.content: As I mentioned earlier,
US jobless claims have fallen to their lowest level since February
â€” dipping by 13,000 to 216,000 claims made in the week ending September 2.
Economists had predicted a relatively small lift to occur in the numbers. So what was behind the change?
Markets economist at NAB,
Taylor Nugent
, notes that the surprise fall could be for a couple of reasons.
"The figures
could have been distorted by holiday factors
, coming a week before Labour Day, and Hurricane Idalia â€“ where the usual reaction after a natural disaster is lower claims initially, followed by a jump," he said in a morning note.
This most recent fall marks the
fourth straight weekly decline in US jobless claims
, and comes after the US Labor Department last week said jobs growth had picked up in August.
All in all, the data suggests the
US job market remains relatively tight
, despite other figures indicating it has started to soften.

image.altText: Russia's President Vladimir Putin, India's PM Narendra Modi and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

items.synopsis: When the G20 began in 2008 against a backdrop of a global economic crisis, nations came together to fix problems both internationally and at home.Â Fifteen years later, the event is struggling to even get a full list of attendees.

title.children: Demolished slums, new roads, and animal control: India is going all out for G20, but is it still relevant?

image.altText: A composite picture ofÂ Qatar Airways and Qantas airliners on the tarmac.

items.synopsis: A decision announced in July to deny Qatar Airways more flights to major Australian cities has resulted in accusations of protectionism for Qantas, criticism from the private sector and ACCC, and a parliamentary inquiry. This is how it all unfolded.

image.altText: German defence officials climb on a Boxer army vehicle in australia

image.altText: A man looking at the camera with a neutral expression with a lounge behind him

image.altText: Belinda and Kobee Huddy smile for a selfie.
